data.content: What is the closest exoplanet to earth?
The closest known exoplanet to Earth is Proxima Centauri b, which is located in the habitable zone of its star, Proxima Centauri. It is approximately 4.2 light-years away from Earth.
How long would it take to travel to it?

The exact duration of a journey to Proxima Centauri b would depend on the technology used for propulsion and the speed of the spacecraft. However, using current technology, it would take a very long time to reach Proxima Centauri b. The fastest spacecraft ever created, NASA's Parker Solar Probe, travels at about 430,000 miles per hour (700,000 kilometers per hour). At this speed, it would take around 6,300 years to reach Proxima Centauri b, assuming a distance of 4.2 light-years.
what if we developed a craft that can travel at the speed of light?

If we were able to develop a spacecraft that could travel at the speed of light, it would theoretically take about 4.2 years to reach Proxima Centauri b. This is because the distance between Earth and Proxima Centauri b is approximately 4.2 light-years. However, it is important to note that according to our current understanding of physics, objects with mass cannot reach or exceed the speed of light. The theory of relativity states that as an object with mass approaches the speed of light, its mass would increase, requiring infinite energy to reach the speed of light. Thus, the idea of traveling at the speed of light is currently considered impractical based on our current scientific knowledge.
